BE11:13am

The simple conclusion is that the broadcasting battle between Sky and BT is over. In the last two auctions a bidding war between BT and Sky drove the total package costs up 70% each time, and at the last auction Sky had to pay 83% to secure more prime time games. Since the decision in December for both companies to sell each other’s channels it became clear that this wasn’t going to be the same nosebleed cost inflation of previous auctions. The cost per game rose to £10.19M in the last auction. The result today for the main five packages REDUCES the cost per game to £9.3M (with two small simultaneous based programmes still under auction), so a decline of 8%. The two remaining packages are what we’d expect to be the least valuable packages which will be the midweek and bank-holiday fixtures, where all the matches will be available to be shown live simultaneously. (2 packages of 20 games each but only 4 time slots per season).

Electric Dragon "Don't spoil Man City v Chelsea for me, I've only got as far as Bournemouth v Everton!"
Kiwi-juice I was stuck with BT shares and they are hardly recovering. 4x EV/EBITDA, 2x dividend cover, pension gap to close with rising rates, now lower programming costs. I do not get it
Swedish Chef Fatdaz. Should have dumped BT a while ago. Hacked off as customer and shareholder.
FATDAZ @Swedish :(
BE11:15am

So Amazon, YouTube, Facebook or Apple might yet pick up a streaming package .... but, not unpredictably, they have no interest in the bundled inertia and rate creep model favoured by Sky and BT.

Kiwi-juice H&M back at 2009 lows. Online retailers killing the industry margins

The lack of content cost hyperinflation eases the path to the attraction of Sky to suitors (first Fox of course, and then Disney, and perhaps this will sharpen the deal pencil of the Roberts family and Comcast). It also comes as a welcome relief to BT which has been battered by a number of headwinds of late but likely cost discipline of this previous loss leading strategy is a step in the right direction.

We think ‘The Street’s’ expectations have been drifting down to c.+15% rights inflation. Against this, there would be a theoretical c.+£400m benefit to PBT for FY20, although we would expect a large portion to be reallocated elsewhere in the business. For a sense of perspective, though, if 50% were to flow down to the bottom line, it would be +12% to FY20 EPS. We regard this as very positive news for Sky, and see it increasing the possibility of a 21CF ‘bump’ to its 1075p indicative cash bid.

FATDAZ @Kiwi Juice thats interesting I gave up trying to short those and Inditex years ago as they kept growing despite massive youth unemployment and recession finally a catalyst for change

It is not yet clear to what extent Sky will reinvest the c.GBP400m saving (vs consensus). It says it will grow programming in line with revenue. However we believe minority investors will now push for a higher offer price from Fox than 1075p. If Sky chose not to reinvest the saving and its final payment is GBP1193m this would raise our 2021 FCF estimate by 46% and DCF by 55%. If the final payment was flat on last time this would raise our 2021 FCF by 35% and DCF value by 44%. The scheme of arrangement needs 75% approval by minority investors so minorities are in a strong position to push for a higher offer p

BE11:26am

FY18 another tough year, online growing strongly
In its press release ahead of the CMD H&M states that Q1 has been difficult with further imbalances in stock levels and high
opening stock levels affecting full price sales. Markdown costs will be higher and will also impact earnings at the start of the
year. FY18 space is expected to be c4%, dropping down to 1-3% for outer years.
Investment in digital and new brands
Online sales are currently c12.5% of sales and are expected to grow by 20-25% pa. Online profitability is strong at 22% of group
EBIT, although more detail on cost allocation would be useful. New brands account for c7% of group sales and are also growing
at 25% pa. Online and new brands will thus drive c5% growth in group sales, mainly LFL but also some within space. Another
two brands will be launched shortly.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Growth expected FY19 and beyond
LFL in physical stores is expected to return to growth from FY19. If this is achieved, and there is growth from online on top, then
total LFL could rise by mid single digits. Markdowns should also decline, leading to “good” increases in profit. Our main concern
would be whether the group acts radically enough to clear current stock levels, which at 17% of sales are much higher than
peers.
Valuation: Neutral, Price Target SEK135
The FY18 guidance may be more downbeat than expected, but outer years looks more encouraging. If the group can place more
substance on these targets today there could be a change in the generally negative view on the stock. We would look for more
guidance also on stock levels and the debt outlook.

BE11:32am

H1 revenue was up 14% with EBITA up 22% and underlying
PBT up 29% at £83m. Very strong performance from the Partnership business along with a healthy pick-up in margins at Linden on an ex land sales basis. Construction continues to normalise with margins up to 0.9%. However, as expected the group has taken a further £25m exceptional charge on the back of the liquidation of Carillion and its involvement in the Aberdeen road project. Net debt was a bit lower than expected at £85m (vs £114m a year ago) with average net debt of £203m vs £231m in H1 2017. The group retains £550m worth of banking facilities. The group has decided to bring forward the move to 2.0x dividend cover for the current year vs our previous forecast of 1.7x, implying a 16p cut to 84p for our dividend estimate for FY18.

The shares have been one of the weaker performers among the housebuilders ytd with a 23% decline led principally by the impact of Carillion's collapse on the Aberdeen road JV. On current forecasts the shares are trading on a P/NAV of PE of 1.7x for CY18 while generating a 33% post-tax RoE. The CY18 PE is 5.5x and the dividend yield on our revised estimate is 8.9%.

BE11:43am

Though the combination of base businesses has been broadly
stable since the Skyepharma merger, the hoped-for transition to
a specialty respiratory hybrid appears to have stalled. Vectura has
cut R&D investment and instituted a buyback programme, and
has reprioritised the pipeline towards generics. All this suggests a
maturing business with few near-term catalysts absent bigger
cash handbacks, more deals and/or a takeover bid, visibility on
all of which is low. We therefore retain our Hold
recommendation despite the upside to our new 120p TP.

BE11:52am

Plus500 reported FY 2017 results this morning which, despite several upgrades through the year, are materially above our estimates. Revenue grew 33% to $437m (3% above our forecast), while EBITDA was up 72% at $259m (8% above our forecast). The margin for the year rose to 59% (2016: 46%). This was driven by a 103% increase in active customer numbers and a 136% increase in new customer signups, while the group’s biggest cost, customer acquisition, fell from $1,195 to $474 per user. As a result, the group will return c$199m to shareholders for FY 2017 (c100% net income), bringing the total to $539m since listing with a market cap of only $200m in 2013.

BE11:53am

High levels of interest in crypto-currency markets allowed the group to gain 151k new customers in Q4 alone (+572% on Q4 2016), more than the total for 2016 (104k). Given the weighting towards the end of the year, the average revenue per user declined to $1,379 (FY 2016: $2,013) but this was more than offset by a decline the average user acquisition cost, which fell to $474 (FY 2016: $1,195). The company now states that only 15% of revenues were generated by CFDs on crypto-currencies as users who initially joined to trade Bitcoin or Ethereum became interested in other asset classes.

Management said it had noted “record financial KPIs” in the early
weeks of 2018, which is impressive given the numbers reported in Q4 2017. The geographic expansion should continue in 2018 (in FY 2017 76% of revenues were generated in Europe) as Plus500 added two new licences in South Africa and Singapore last year, on top of those it holds in the UK, Australia, Cyprus, New Zealand and Israel. The regulatory landscape remains uncertain but the European Securities and Markets Association (“ESMA”) is expected to reveal its final proposals in H1 2018. Even if enacted in their current form, management does not believe that they would have a “material adverse effect” on the business because the company already adheres to almost all the proposals (eg no net gain from market P&L, no negative balances no binary options or bonuses). We are cautiously optimistic that these rules will not affect the business as much as the market fears.

We have rolled forward our model to add explicit forecasts for 2020E, and updated our forecasts to reflect both the FY 2017 result and management’s positive comments about Q1 2018. This leads us to increase our EBITDA forecasts by 31%/37%/44% for 2018E-20E. As a result, we raise our price target to 1,540p (from 1200p).

We note that the proposed leverage restrictions apply to retail clients only and that there may be an opportunity to exempt appropriate customers by establishing their status as "professional."
